questions.text: The average daily dietary nutrient intake level sufficient to meet the nutrient requirements of nearly all (97-98%) healthy individuals in a particular life stage and gender group is known as (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Recommended dietary allowance

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA)
  • ➤ Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA)
  • ➤ Definition: RDA is a level of intake corresponding to Mean + 2 Standard Deviation, which covers requirement of 97.5% of population RDA is safe level of intake which is likely to be inadequate in not more than 2.5% population RDA is decided by a panel of experts and is based on scientific research RDA is often higher than the recommended minimum requirement: RDA includes both daily requirement and some additional requirement for periods of growth or illness RDA is based on Estimated Average Requirement RDA ‘safe level approach’ is not used for energy since excess energy intake is undesirable. For energy: only mean or average requirement is defined as RDA.
  • ➤ Definition: RDA is a level of intake corresponding to Mean + 2 Standard Deviation, which covers requirement of 97.5% of population
  • ➤ RDA is safe level of intake which is likely to be inadequate in not more than 2.5% population
  • ➤ RDA is decided by a panel of experts and is based on scientific research
  • ➤ RDA is often higher than the recommended minimum requirement: RDA includes both daily requirement and some additional requirement for periods of growth or illness
  • ➤ RDA is based on Estimated Average Requirement
  • ➤ RDA ‘safe level approach’ is not used for energy since excess energy intake is undesirable.
  • ➤ For energy: only mean or average requirement is defined as RDA.

questions.text: Identify the structure being palpated in the image: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Posterior tibial artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The posterior tibial artery can be palpated just behind the medial malleolus, and this is a key location for assessing the arterial blood supply to the foot.

questions.text: A patient complained of ear discharge, retro-orbital pain, and visual disturbances. What is the diagnosis: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Petrositis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gradenigo's syndrome (Petrositis) presents with the triad of ear discharge, retro-orbital pain, and sixth nerve palsy causing visual disturbances. This is due to the spread of chronic ear infection to the petrous apex of the temporal bone, affecting adjacent cranial nerves.

questions.text: Personal monitoring of radiation is done by:(NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. TLD badge

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Personal monitoring of radiation is done by a TLD badge.
  • • Given to radiation personnel for its usage. Personnel dosimeter. Thermoluminescent 3 monthly [sent for measurement in India] Made up of CaSO 4 : Dysprosium [LiF can also be used] Worn below the lead apron at the level of the chest
  • • Given to radiation personnel for its usage.
  • • Personnel dosimeter.
  • • Thermoluminescent
  • • 3 monthly [sent for measurement in India]
  • • Made up of CaSO 4 : Dysprosium [LiF can also be used]
  • • Worn below the lead apron at the level of the chest
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Collimators: Used in radiographic devices to narrow the beam of radiation to limit exposure and improve image quality, but not for monitoring radiation exposure.
  • • Option A. Collimators:
  • • Option C. Linear accelerator: A device primarily used in cancer treatment to deliver high-energy x-rays or electrons to the region of the patient's tumor. It is not a monitoring device.
  • • Option C. Linear accelerator:
  • • Option D. Grid: Used in radiographic imaging to improve image contrast by absorbing scattered radiation, not for measuring radiation exposure.
  • • Option D. Grid:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A TLD badge is a critical tool for radiation safety, allowing for accurate monitoring and measurement of radiation exposure over time to ensure that radiation workers do not exceed safe exposure limits. This is crucial in maintaining occupational health standards in radiologically active environments.

questions.text: Which of the following is a gram-positive organism that shows the following appearance on Ziehl-Neelsen staining? ( INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Nocardia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nocardia can be identified by its branching filamentous structure on gram stain and weak acid-fast positivity due to the presence of mycolic acid in its cell wall, distinguishing it from other gram-positive and acid-fast organisms.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl lately having poor scholastic performance. She complains of hearing loss for which she was brought to the clinic by her parents. She breathes with her mouth and has a low tone voice. The X-ray has been performed. On audiometry, 30dB of Bilateral CHL is diagnosed. What could be the best treatment for her? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The girl presents with symptoms of adenoid hypertrophy, including mouth breathing, low tone voice, and poor scholastic performance.
  • • The lateral view X-ray shows soft tissue opacification in the nasopharynx, indicative of adenoid hypertrophy.
  • • The audiometry results show bilateral conductive hearing loss (CHL) at 30dB, likely due to eustachian tube blockage and serous otitis media caused by the enlarged adenoids.
  • • The best treatment for this condition is adenoidectomy to remove the hypertrophied adenoids and grommet insertion to drain the middle ear fluid and alleviate the conductive hearing loss.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Adenoidectomy with Myringotomy: While adenoidectomy addresses the root cause, myringotomy without grommet insertion may not adequately resolve the middle ear fluid and could lead to recurrent effusions.
  • • Option A. Adenoidectomy with Myringotomy:
  • • Option B. Bone anchored hearing aid: This option is typically used for specific types of hearing loss and is not the first-line treatment for conductive hearing loss caused by adenoid hypertrophy and associated otitis media.
  • • Option B. Bone anchored hearing aid:
  • • Option C. Myringotomy with grommet insertion: This addresses the middle ear effusion but does not treat the underlying cause of the adenoid hypertrophy, which would likely result in recurrent issues.
  • • Option C. Myringotomy with grommet insertion:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The combination of adenoidectomy and grommet insertion effectively addresses both the cause (adenoid hypertrophy) and the symptom (middle ear effusion), providing a comprehensive treatment for bilateral conductive hearing loss in children.

questions.text: A patient presented in the ENT OPD with nasal obstruction. On examination, a mulberry-shaped hypertrophied inferior turbinate was observed. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Hypertrophic Rhinitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hypertrophic Rhinitis involves chronic inflammation leading to noticeable enlargement and characteristic textural changes in the nasal turbinates, often requiring a combination of medical and surgical treatments to manage symptoms effectively and improve nasal airflow.

questions.text: In the bustling streets of Mumbai, a young filmmaker is working on a documentary about the impact of media on public opinion. During his interviews with several media experts, he encounters the term "propaganda" frequently. Intrigued, he decides to explore this concept further and learns that it plays a significant role in shaping public perception. In the context of media and communication, which of the following best describes the essence of "propaganda"?(FMGE JAN 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Trying to make them think for themselves

questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Appeals to emotions

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Supracondylar humerus fracture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cubitus varus , a "gunstock" deformity, is a classic complication of malunited supracondylar humerus fractures in children, where the carrying angle is reduced, causing medial deviation of the arm.

  • ➤ supracondylar humerus fractures

questions.text: During neonatal resuscitation at which heart rate you will start chest compression? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Heart rate less than 60

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Neonatal Resuscitation algorithm-2015 update

questions.text: A pediatric resident is preparing a presentation on neonatal mortality in India. She finds a dataset from the verbal autopsy report (2010-2013) and wants to understand the hierarchy of factors contributing to neonatal deaths. Based on this data, how would you arrange these factors from the most significant contributor to the least? (INICET NOV 2021) Prematurity and low birth weight Birth injuries and birth asphyxia Congenital anomalies Sepsis
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1>2>4>3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Causes of Neonatal mortality (0 – 4 weeks):
  • ➤ Low birth weight and prematurity Birth injury and difficult labour Sepsis Congenital anomalies Hemolytic diseases of newborn Conditions of placenta and cord Diarrhoeal diseases Acute respiratory infections Tetanus
  • ➤ Low birth weight and prematurity
  • ➤ Birth injury and difficult labour
  • ➤ Sepsis
  • ➤ Congenital anomalies
  • ➤ Hemolytic diseases of newborn
  • ➤ Conditions of placenta and cord
  • ➤ Diarrhoeal diseases
  • ➤ Acute respiratory infections
  • ➤ Tetanus
  • ➤ According to WHO, Preterm birth, intrapartum-related complications (birth asphyxia), infections and congenital defects are the leading causes of most neonatal deaths.

questions.text: In a case of fatality resulting from firearm injuries, the entrance wound displays solely an abrasion collar. The firearm's firing distance probably is? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Distant range

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ There are five features of firearm entry wound (inner most to outermost):
  • ➤ Grease Collar (inner most) Abrasion collar Singeing Blackening Tattooing (outer most)
  • ➤ Grease Collar (inner most)
  • ➤ Abrasion collar
  • ➤ Singeing
  • ➤ Blackening
  • ➤ Tattooing (outer most)
  • ➤ Out of these five features, Abrasion collar and Grease collar can be found in any entry wound, irrespective of the distance between victim and firearm. This is because these are produced by bullet itself as it enters the body.
  • ➤ Abrasion collar and Grease collar
  • ➤ can be found in any entry wound, irrespective of the distance between victim and firearm.
  • ➤ Whereas Singeing, Blackening and Tattooing occur only upto a limited distance
  • ➤ Singeing, Blackening and Tattooing occur only upto a limited distance

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the OPD with a parietal swelling present since birth. An X-ray was ordered and is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Cephalhematoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cephalhematoma is a localized hematoma under the periosteum of the skull bone in newborns, confined by suture lines and typically associated with birth trauma.

questions.text: After reaching an equilibrium state during exercising, it was found that the body was consuming oxygen at the rate of 1500 ml/min. Calculate the MET score if the baseline oxygen consumption at rest is 250 ml/min? ( INICET Nov 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 6

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The MET score represents the energy expenditure of an activity as a multiple of the resting metabolic rate.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman came for a routine antenatal check-up in her second trimester. Four years back, she delivered 2 healthy full-term twins. What would her obstetric score be? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) G2P1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A twin pregnancy that has crossed the period of viability is considered as Para 1, not Para 2. If it results in two living children, it will be Live 2.

  • ➤ Ref: Page no 469, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman who is being treated for infertility with human menopausal gonadotropin presented with complaints of sudden abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and breathlessness. The finding of the ultrasound is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) is characterized by multiple follicular development and ovarian enlargement following hCG stimulation, with symptoms including abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and breathlessness, often visible on ultrasound as enlarged ovaries with large cysts.

questions.text: Identify the incision made and marked is the image: (INICET Nov 2023)

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presented with back pain for the past 3 months. On examination, he has pallor, and gamma globulins are elevated. LFT is normal. X-ray spine shows multiple lytic lesions. Which of the following cells are involved in the pathogenesis of this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Plasma cells

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient's presentation is consistent with multiple myeloma , a plasma cell neoplasm. Key diagnostic features include:
  • • multiple myeloma
  • • Back pain: Common in multiple myeloma due to bone involvement. Pallor: Indicates anemia, a common finding in multiple myeloma. Elevated gamma globulins: Suggests a monoclonal protein spike (M spike) on serum protein electrophoresis. Multiple lytic lesions on X-ray: Classic radiographic finding in multiple myeloma due to bone destruction.
  • • Back pain: Common in multiple myeloma due to bone involvement.
  • • Back pain:
  • • Pallor: Indicates anemia, a common finding in multiple myeloma.
  • • Pallor:
  • • Elevated gamma globulins: Suggests a monoclonal protein spike (M spike) on serum protein electrophoresis.
  • • Elevated gamma globulins:
  • • Multiple lytic lesions on X-ray: Classic radiographic finding in multiple myeloma due to bone destruction.
  • • Multiple lytic lesions on X-ray:
  • • In multiple myeloma, malignant clonal plasma cells proliferate in the bone marrow, leading to the production of abnormal monoclonal immunoglobulins, bone destruction, and marrow infiltration.
  • • plasma cells
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A, B & D: Not primarily involved in multiple myeloma.
  • • Option A, B & D:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Multiple myeloma is a plasma cell neoplasm characterized by anemia, elevated gamma globulins, and lytic bone lesions, with plasma cells being the key pathological cells involved.

questions.text: In skeletal muscle, dihydropyridine and ryanodine receptors are coupled by?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Mechanically

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In skeletal muscle, the dihydropyridine and ryanodine receptors are coupled mechanically, meaning their interaction and functional coupling rely on direct physical contacts between these protein structures to initiate muscle contraction.

questions.text: Collapse in a patient during labor/ delivery followed by bleeding and DIC in the absence of coexisting conditions is most likely due to? (NEET PG 2022)

questions.text: The table provided illustrates a multivariate analysis assessing the relationship between the risk of blindness and various factors including age, literacy rate, place of residence, and gender. Which of the subsequent statements accurately interprets this data? (INICET MAY 2022) Female population is at greater risk of developing blindness. People dwelling in rural areas are at increased risk of developing blindness. Risk of developing blindness increases with age. Illiteracy leads to increased risk of developing blindness.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 3 and 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Odds ratio interpretation:
  • ➤ Odds ratio interpretation:
  • ➤ Odds ratio of 1: Indicates that the risk factor is not related to the disease. Odds ratio less than 1: Indicates that a person with the disease is less likely to have been exposed to the factor, implying that the factor may be protective. Odds ratio greater than 1: Indicates that the factor is associated with an increased risk of the disease.
  • ➤ Odds ratio of 1: Indicates that the risk factor is not related to the disease.
  • ➤ Odds ratio of 1:
  • ➤ Odds ratio less than 1: Indicates that a person with the disease is less likely to have been exposed to the factor, implying that the factor may be protective.
  • ➤ Odds ratio less than 1:
  • ➤ Odds ratio greater than 1: Indicates that the factor is associated with an increased risk of the disease.
  • ➤ Odds ratio greater than 1:
  • ➤ p-value interpretation:
  • ➤ p-value interpretation:
  • ➤ p-value < 0.05: Indicates that the result is statistically significant. p-value > 0.05: Indicates that the result is not statistically significant.
  • ➤ p-value < 0.05: Indicates that the result is statistically significant.
  • ➤ p-value < 0.05:
  • ➤ p-value > 0.05: Indicates that the result is not statistically significant.
  • ➤ p-value > 0.05:

questions.text: Transcutaneous electric nerve stimulation is used to reduce pain. What is the mechanism behind this?(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Gate control theory

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) reduces pain through the gate control theory, which involves blocking pain signals at the spinal cord level by activating large diameter afferent fibers.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a dietary fiber? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Milk

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Major components of dietary fiber are cellulose, hemicelluloses, D-glucans, pectin, lignin and gums. Cellulose, hemicelluloses and pectin are partially degradable, while other components are indigestible. Dietary fiber also contains minerals, antioxidants and other chemicals that are useful for health.
  • • Sources of dietary fiber are fruits, vegetables, cereals, bread and wheat grain (particularly its outer layer).
  • • Diet with high dietary fiber has health benefits since dietary fiber:
  • • Delays emptying of stomach Increases formation of bulk and soft feces and eases defecation Contains substances such as antioxidants and other useful substances
  • • Delays emptying of stomach
  • • Increases formation of bulk and soft feces and eases defecation
  • • Contains substances such as antioxidants and other useful substances
  • • Diet with high fiber content tends to be low in energy and it may be useful in reducing the body weight.
  • • Some components of dietary fiber also reduce blood cholesterol level and thereby decrease the risk for coronary heart disease and gallstones.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Cellulose : A primary form of dietary fiber found in the cell walls of plants.
  • • Option A. Cellulose
  • • Option B. Inulin : A type of soluble fiber found in many plants, used by some as a prebiotic to promote gut health.
  • • Option B. Inulin
  • • Option C. Pectin : Another soluble fiber, pectin is commonly found in fruits and used to help gel liquids, also aiding in digestion and cholesterol reduction.
  • • Option C. Pectin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective

questions.text: In which of the following scenarios is a liver transplant possible in the case of secondary tumours? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ca testis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Liver transplantation for metastatic cancer is rare and generally only considered under specific conditions. These conditions typically include the isolation of metastasis to the liver, good control of the primary cancer, and a lack of other effective treatment options. Each type of cancer must be evaluated on its own characteristics, including its responsiveness to treatment and overall prognosis.

questions.text: A newborn baby is born with a congenital defect. Identify the defect shown in the image: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Bladder Exstrophy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bladder Exstrophy is characterized by the bladder being exposed outside the body, appearing as a red mass in the lower abdomen with no covering membrane. It differs from other abdominal wall defects like omphalocele and gastroschisis, which involve the protrusion of abdominal contents with or without a protective sac.

questions.explanation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rigor mortis follows a sequence known as Nysten's Rule, developing and passing from head to foot, starting with the upper body and ending with the lower extremities.

questions.text: A female patient presents to you with a unilateral headache. It is associated with nausea, photophobia, and phonophobia. What is the best drug for acute management? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
